NYUAD Library

This guide was created by Amani Magid, Science and Engineering Librarian, from the NYUAD Library.  If you have any questions or suggestions, please contact us at nyuad.library@nyu.edu. 

About Imagine Science Film Festival Abu Dhabi

Imagine Science Film Festival Abu Dhabi is a film and sci-art festival with a focus on science/engineering. The Abu Dhabi festival is now in its second season at New York University Abu Dhabi. The festival consists of short and feature film screenings, along with panel discussions, Q&As, talks, workshops and performances on science subjects and subjects inspired from science. All festival activities are free of charge.

Film Festival: February 18-20

Art Exhibition: February 18-23

Imagine Science Film Festival began more than eight years ago in New York City and was founded by Alexis Gambis, who is the executive director and also an Assistant Professor of Biology, Film and New Media. Alexis saw that there was a dearth of films about science and felt that film would be a great avenue for presenting science concepts to the public. Therefore, after obtaining doctorate and masters's degrees in the sciences, he obtained an MFA in film from NYU. Since then he has been actively producing films on science and founded Imagine Science Film Festival so that he and other filmmakers can have a platform for presenting science-themed films to the public.

Student Film Lab

About

SOURCE

The Student Film Lab is the outreach of Imagine Science Film Festival. Students from high schools in Abu Dhabi are recruited to take part in a lab in which they create their own film. The students are given a couple of weeks to film their footage and they are then given a quick course in film editing. According to Imagine Science "Our goal is to help students create a window into the world of a science lab, enabling them to appreciate science through the filmmaking process and then to share the results with others".

This year's theme is "Air above us, air around us".

Events

STUDENT FILM LAB LAUNCH-JANUARY 25

Students record video using their mobile devices.

WORKSHOP-FEBRUARY 2 & 4, NYUAD Institute

Students spend the morning listening to different aspects of filmmaking from guest lectures. In the afternoon, students are taught how to edit their videos from NYUAD Film Instructors.

SCREENING-FEBRUARY 17: 3pm-5pm, NYUAD Arts Center Black Box Theatre

All films created at the Student Film Lab will be shown

EXHIBIT-FEBRUARY 18-23

February 18-20 12:00PM-10:00PM

February 21-23  12:00PM-8:00PM

All student films and other films will be shown on loop in the exhibit

 

 

STEM VS STEAM INFOGRAPHIC

SOURCE

 

Organizations incorporating arts into STEM Education

  • STEM to STEAM
    Founded by the Rhode Island School of Design, this organization ecourages incorporating art and design to help students learn about science, technology, engineering and mathematics.
  • STEAM not STEM
    Our mission is to have business leaders, arts professionals, educators and others work together to educate governments, the public and the media to the need for returning Arts to the national curricula.
  • Edutopia-STEM to STEAM: Resources Toolkit
    Whether you are looking for resources on integrating science, technology, engineering, and math or on infusing the arts to transform STEM into STEAM, these curated compilations will help you plan different approaches to integrated studies.

LIterature on use of film for teaching STEM students

  • (Re)Counting Meaningful Learning Experiences: Using Student-Created Reflective Videos to Make Invisible Learning Visible During PjBL Experiences by Smith, Shaunna
    Publication Date: Apr 2016
    This ethnographic case study investigated how the process of learning during a yearlong after-school, project-based learning (PjBL) experience could be documented by student-created reflective videos. Guided by social constructivism, constant comparative analysis was used to explore the meaningful learning that took place in addition to the planned curricula, resulting in an exploration of the intersections of life lessons that include (a) "making learning more real," (b) being "on a mission to change the world," and (c) "you can't control anybody but yourself." Findings from the study indicate that student-created reflective videos can document meaningful learning that is capable of "counting" both as a creative form of self-expression and an alternative form of measuring the learning process throughout PjBL. [ABSTRACT FROM AUTHOR]
  • Motion picture science: A fully integrated fine Arts/STEM degree program. by Scholl, Victoria M. Iafrati, Megan M. Long, David L. Pow, Joseph J.
    Publication Date: 2014 2014 IEEE Integrated STEM Education Conference

Sci-Art Exhibition

Atmospheres

Atmosphere is an exhibit that looks at the crossroads of science and art. It features gallery talks, film showings, and more! This year's exhibit is centered around the theme of Atmospheres in both a literal and metaphonic sense.

http://www.nyuad-artscenter.org/en_US/events/2016/sci-art-exhibition/

Learn about Science in Film

Featured Database

 

A comprehensive index covering the entire spectrum of television and film writing and produced for a broad target audience, from film scholars to general viewers. Subject coverage includes: film & television theory, preservation & restoration, writing, production, cinematography, technical aspects, and reviews. Dates of coverage: 1914 to present.

Go to this Database!

Google Scholar Search

Use Google Scholar to find out what's been written about your topic:

Relevant themes and keywords

Intrigued by Imagine Science Film Festival and want to find out more?  You may find the following keywords helpful as you search NYU's music databases listed below:

  • Science AND film NOT fiction
  • STEM education AND film
  • Science AND documentary

Find more in these databases

  • EBSCO Discovery Service
    EBSCO Discovery Service (EDS) encompasses articles in databases across many disciplines. Users can locate peer reviewed articles, videos, audio files, images, and more from a range of subjects.
  • Arts and Humanities Citation Index (A&HCI)
    This database indexes about 1,700 arts and humanities journals. Dates of coverage: 1975 to present.
    Adjust settings to expand your searching to include the Social Sciences Citation Index, the Science Citation Index, the Book Citation Index, and others.
  • Film Literature Index
    Indexes 150 film and television periodicals from 30 countries cover-to-cover and 200 other periodicals selectively for articles on film and television. The periodicals range from the scholarly to the popular. Contains approximately 700,000 citations to articles, film reviews and book reviews published between 1976-2001.
  • Scopus
    Find articles in the sciences and use the citation index to discover citations of relevant articles.
  • Web of Science
    Search for articles in the sciences and the articles that cite them.

Films on science in the Library

Here are a sampling of films available at the NYUAD Library. To look at all of our films use the following search terms: "Science film NOT fiction". Under "Limit to" click on Video.

  • The Harriman Alaska Expedition retraced
    Call Number: DVDAD 4539
    Two scientific expeditions to Alaska, 100 years apart, give an unparalleled view of environmental damage and the change in society's attitudes.
  • The wisdom to survive : climate change, capitalism & community
    Call Number: DVDAD 4458
    "The wisdom to survive accepts the consensus of scientists that climate change has already arrived, and asks, what is keeping us from action? The film explores how unlimited growth and greed are destroying the life support system of the planet, the social fabric of society, and the lives of billions of people. Will we have the wisdom to survive? The film features thought leaders and activists in the realms of science, economics and spirituality discussing how we can evolve and take action in the face of climate disruption. They urge us to open ourselves to the beauty that surrounds us and get to work on ensuring it thrives. Among those featured are Bill McKibben, Joanna Macy, Nikki Cooley, Roger Payne, Richard Heinberg, Amy Seidl, Stephanie Kaza, Gus Speth, Jihan Gearan, and Ben Falk"
  • Dirty paradise
    Call Number: DVDAD 4837 P
    Today an incredible sanitary and ecological disaster is taking place in the heart of the Amazonia in an overseas department of France, on the border between Suriman and French Guyana. Dirty Paradise shares the story of a thousand Indians who are trying to survive the devastation caused by 10,000 illegal gold-seekers who hide in the forests.
  • Natural State. Episode 26
    Call Number: Available online
    Pollution Measuring - A facility in Leicester examining levels of pollution around the world. Renewable Energy Forum - A two day forum looking at alternative energy sources available to consumers. Drinking Straw - A look at a new straw that acts as a filter and makes any water anywhere instantly drinkable. Ocean Science Study - A research centre to study all components of ocean science. Ballooning - A look at the benefits of this eco-friendly tourist attraction. Solar Car Improvements - Here we look at the new developments for the British car in the Trans Australia Solar Race. Cambodia Bio-gas - An alternative cooking method in this impoverished country. India Solar Power - Remote villagers are finding enormous benefits from this new source of power. Antarctic Dry Valley - Scientists are studying volcanic activity in this harsh environment. UK Coral - Here we look at a unique eco - system off the coast of England containing a rare breed of coral.
  • Earth : the power of the planet
    Call Number: DVDAD 670
    Travelling from Ethiopia's unique lava lake to an ice cave under a glacier in Greenland and a host of amazing locations in between, we examine the forces that have helped create and foster life on Earth - from the volcanic eruptions that shaped the land to the development of the unique formula of the air that we breathe.
  • Through the looking glass : the mirror and the self-conscious
    Call Number: DVDAD 4658
    When do humans develop self-consciousness and recognition of others as separate beings? Do these psychological advancements occur differently in animals? Many scientists think so, using the most advanced of scientific equipment to base their conclusions: the common mirror. This engaging and sometimes surprising documentary builds a case for the mirror's role in determining the stages of psychological progress in humans and animals. Field experiments conducted by Jim Anderson, researcher in psychology at Sterling University in Scotland, illustrate how the mirror's secrets teach much about the intelligence of the animal world.
  • The linguists
    Call Number: DVDAD 4720 1 teacher's guide
    Joins David Harrison and Gregory Anderson, scientists racing to document languages on the verge of extinction. In Siberia, India and Bolivia, David and Greg's resolve is tested by the very forces stifling languages: institutionalized racism and violent economic unrest. The scientists must overcome their own fears and preconceived notions to draw speakers from decades of silence. Their journey takes them deep into the heart of the cultures, knowledge, and communities at stake.
  • The Race for the double helix
    Call Number: DVDAD 3424
    Set in the years 1951-1953 and told from the point of view of the young scientist James "Jim" Watson, this film portrays the discovery of the double helix comprising human genetic material. According to the film, the discovery was primarily made by woman scientist Rosalind Franklin, but her ideas were stolen by the team of Watson, Crick and Wilkins who were subsequently awarded the Nobel Prize.

NYUAD Library

NYUAD Library

The library facility provides spaces for engagement between faculty and students, complemented by quiet areas for concentration and contemplation. Service to scholars is the primary mission of the NYUAD library staff. Value is placed on saving time for researchers, providing requested items efficiently, informing scholars of new resources and offering assistance in finding, using, analyzing, and presenting knowledge.

The NYUAD Library offers a growing print collection and access to myriad electronic resources via NYU New York:

  • 90,000 journal titles
  • 1,000+ databases
  • Nearly a million e-books, audio, and video files

These electronic resources are accessible within the library and remotely. NYUAD users can also request books from NYU New York's 3.9-million-title collection.

Comfortable reading areas and small and large group study rooms create a productive atmosphere for research. The dedicated silent study area on the Mezzanine level provides plenty of space for students to focus on their research in a relaxed environment.

Reference and research assistance is currently available via telephone, email, chat, and in-person at our Information Desk.

Information for Visitors

The NYUAD Library is primarily intended for use by our faculty, students, and staff. Members of the Abu Dhabi community may be granted library privileges through the Visiting Scholar program. If you have a special research need that requires the use of our library, please apply for this program using the Visiting Scholar Application (PDF).
